title: AI as a Mirror
text:
We often talk about AI as something alien, a perspective that is exaggerated by Hollywood through artificial intelligence world domination. In reality, however, AI is something that originates from us.
This blog post will explore this through my conversation with ChatGPT.
I asked ChatGPT what it thinks of itself. This is its response.

Then, I asked ChatGPT to explain how it worked.
It said that it is a large language model tha is trained on lots of text data so that it can recognize patterns in language and generate responses.
Step by step: 1) You give input ‚Äì your message is turned into numbers (tokens) that represent words and phrases. 2) ChatGPT process it ‚Äì it uses a neural network to evaluate what responses make sense. 3) ChatGPT generate output ‚Äì it predict the next word, then the next, and so on, until I form a full answer.

title: AI as a Mirror
section: What I think about ChatGPT as a LLM
text:
What I think about ChatGPT as a LLM
I believe that ChatGPT is a very useful tool but it has many limitations. It lacks the capabilities to ‚Äúthink‚Äù in the human sense‚Äìit doesn‚Äôt have beliefs, feelings, or intentions‚Äìand don‚Äôt have live memory of past conversations unless reminded.
When taken with a grain of salt, ChatGPT makes a great conversation partner that can expand on your ideas and help you see the bigger picture.
Over time, however, large language models will come to hold influence in every aspect of life, in every field or industry.

Here is an image of ChatGPT that it generated. What does this tell us?

ChatGPT understands that it is a robot that has the ability to think in a way that is limited by its code.
I then asked, ‚ÄúWhat decisions did you have to make to create this image‚Äù and this is how it responded:

Style ‚Üí I leaned toward a flat, simple, cartoon-like design because it‚Äôs approachable and clear.
Colors ‚Üí Neutral beige background with dark blue outlines and white filling to keep it minimalistic and easy to read.
ymbols ‚Üí A speech bubble (language/communication), lightbulb (ideas/creativity), and gear (technology/process).
Character design ‚Üí A friendly robot figure with a smile, rounded shapes, and a ‚ÄúAI‚Äù label to make it recognizable as an AI, not a human.

Then it said this:

All of these ‚Äúchoices‚Äù came from translating your prompt into visual elements that best match what people might imagine when they picture ‚Äúan AI like me.‚Äù

Rather, this image is created from people‚Äôs (or rather, users‚Äô) image of ChatGPT instead of ChatGPT‚Äôs self perception.
In conclusion, artificial intelligence‚Äîespecially large language models‚Äîact as a mirror of human imagination, there is a gap between function and perception, and the AI identity is co-constructed.

title: The Limits of AI Creativity
text:
Where the Limits Show
But when it comes to originality, AI‚Äôs creative edge dulls. Because LLMs don‚Äôt create from lived experience, emotional depth, or a true understanding of context, they are unable to generate creative or original experiences. That is why they generate based on patterns in their training data.
Another limitation is coherence across long works. Sustaining a novel-length text usually exposes weaknesses: repetitive phrasing and plotlines without purpose.

title: The Limits of AI Creativity
text:
Why It Matters
LLMs are incredible tools for sparking ideas, drafting first versions, or even playing or experimenting with language. But the ‚Äúsoul‚Äù of creativity that is rooted in perspective and genuine insight still belongs to humans.
This is an example that ChatGPT generated when prompted:

However, as evidently shown by this AI-generated picture, there is not a significant difference.
So, what does this tell us about AI‚Äôs creativity and humans‚Äô genuine creativity? Can creativity truly be replicated? If so, what does this tell us about the future of humanity?

First of all, what is the difference between artifical creativity and genuine creativity? This is what ChatGPT said:

Do you agree with it?
Second, when asked if creativity can be replicated, this is what ChatGPT said:

My opinion is that creativity is objectively subjective. While the path that humanity will walk alongside with artificial intelligence is still obscure, it is safe to tell that AI will never fully replace the human impulse to create, but will inevitably reshape how we deifne and practice creativity. Machines can generate works that surprise and delight us but the meaning we attach to those works‚Äîand the emotional depth that inspires them‚Äîremains uniquely human.
The future, then, is not a contest between artificial and genuine creativity, but a collaboration that forces us to rethink what it means to make something truly original.

title: Can ChatGPT solve NYT‚Äôs Connections Game?
text:
I play Connections almost every morning. It‚Äôs the New York Times word puzzle where you‚Äôre given 16 words, and the challenge is to group them into four categories of four. Sounds simple ‚Äî until you realize the words have multiple meanings, decoys, and sneaky overlaps that make it trickier than it looks.
This time, I decided to test a new teammate: ChatGPT. Could it solve the puzzle faster than I could?

Input the Command
I wanted to see if ChatGPT can solve the New York Times Connections Game. Thus, I copied the day‚Äôs words into ChatGPT with a single prompt.
Can you solve the NYT connections game? Here are the words:
BANK, COAST, SHORE, STRAND, CHEMISTRY, CONNECTION, FIREWORKS, SPARK, CARPET, LAMINATE, TILE, WOOD, BANSHEE, HEARTBREAKER, PIP, WAILER
ChatGPT thought for a few seconds and then gave me this:
Thought for 13s

Nice ‚Äî here's a clean solve with groups and category names:

Groups

Shore / Edge (coastline/banks)
BANK, COAST, SHORE, STRAND

Romantic spark / chemistry (things that signal attraction)
CHEMISTRY, CONNECTION, SPARK, FIREWORKS

Flooring materials
CARPET, LAMINATE, TILE, WOOD

Band-name roots (singular forms of group names used in band names: The ___s)
BANSHEE, HEARTBREAKER, PIP, WAILER

Want me to explain any one group in more detail?


Testing It Out
I typed these into the game. And‚Ä¶ it worked! All four groups, correct.



How It Solved It
When I asked ChatGPT how it reached the answer, it broke its process down step by step:
Nice ‚Äî here's a clear, non-secret walkthrough of how I solved it.

1. **Look for obvious semantic clusters.**
   I scanned the full list for small groups of words that share a single, simple meaning. Four words jump out immediately as geographic/edge words: **BANK, COAST, SHORE, STRAND** ‚Äî all refer to edges of land/water, so they form the ‚Äúshore/edge‚Äù group.

2. **Spot metaphorical/figurative connections.**
   Some words weren‚Äôt literal but are commonly used as metaphors for the same idea. **CHEMISTRY, CONNECTION, SPARK, FIREWORKS** are all used to describe romantic or interpersonal attraction (e.g., ‚Äúthere‚Äôs a spark,‚Äù ‚Äúthey have chemistry,‚Äù ‚Äúit felt like fireworks‚Äù), so they cluster as a single figurative category.

3. **Group by concrete category / function.**
   **CARPET, LAMINATE, TILE, WOOD** are all flooring materials ‚Äî a tidy, concrete category that‚Äôs easy to see once you notice two or three of them.

4. **Recognize cultural/name patterns.**
   The last four required a bit of cultural knowledge: **BANSHEE, HEARTBREAKER, PIP, WAILER** all appear in band names (or groups): e.g., *Siouxsie and the Banshees*, *Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers*, *Gladys Knight & The Pips*, *Bob Marley & The Wailers*. That pattern ‚Äî roots that complete well-known band names ‚Äî is the fourth group.

5. **Check for overlap or alternate fits.**
   After grouping, I scanned for words that might belong to more than one group and chose the group where the meaning is strongest and clearest. Example: *strand* can mean thread, but with *bank/coast/shore* present, ‚Äústrand = beach/shore‚Äù is the dominant fit. If there were ambiguity that left multiple plausible groupings, I‚Äôd try different combinations (NYT Connections sometimes has tricky decoys), but here the four groups are clean.

That‚Äôs it ‚Äî a mix of looking for tight literal sets, spotting figurative uses, and recognizing cultural naming conventions. Want me to try a different valid category name for any group (e.g., a snappier label for the band group)?

That‚Äôs not far off from how a human would explain their own reasoning ‚Äî but instead of trial and error on the board and using up limited attempts, the AI laid out categories almost instantly.


AI vs.¬†Human Play Style
What struck me is how differently AI and humans approach the same puzzle:

Humans often guess, regroup, and backtrack when categories overlap.
ChatGPT skipped the guessing and presented neat, confident sets, backed with cultural references and metaphors.

It didn‚Äôt feel like it was ‚Äúplaying‚Äù so much as sorting words into buckets based on context clues it had seen before.
ChatGPT‚Äôs categories were perfect this time, but what impressed me was its confidence. Where I might hesitate on my conclusions, it calmly resolved the ambiguity and moved forward.
The cultural (the hardest!) category was the most surprising. I didn‚Äôt expect an AI to recognize WAILER as a band-name root without hesitation, but it pulled that from its knowledge base right away. Even I didn‚Äôt know that those group of words could form a category.


Should You Play with an AI Teammate?
Would I use ChatGPT every day to ‚Äúcheat‚Äù at Connections? Probably not ‚Äî that would ruin the fun. But it was fascinating to see how it thinks through puzzles like this.
It also raises a bigger question: was this ‚Äúreasoning‚Äù or just sophisticated pattern-matching? To me, it felt like a blend. The AI doesn‚Äôt ‚Äúfeel‚Äù a spark in romance, but it knows that spark + chemistry + fireworks + connection often appear in the same contexts.
This made me wonder ‚Äî how well could ChatGPT handle other NYT puzzles? Wordle seems too easy, but what about Spelling Bee? Or even the Mini Crossword? Until then, it‚Äôs safe to conclude that ChatGPT can solve Connections ‚Äî quickly, neatly, and efficiently.

title: Give me a riddle from ChatGPT
text:
The prompt I asked ChatGPT is to ‚Äúgive me a riddle.‚Äù This is what it said:
I speak without a mouth, and hear without ears. I have no body, but I come alive with the wind.
What am I?
Can you guess it?
I guessed a windchime because a friend thought that the answer was a windchime. :(
Here is another one:
The more you take from me, the bigger I get.
What am I?
Can you guess it?
I guessed a hole and this time, I got it right! Good job, me!

title: Give me a riddle from ChatGPT
section: What I learned from this experience
text:
What I learned from this experience
I learned that ChatGPT is very smart and that LLM is a very complex machine. There are infinite possibilities and that I can continue asking ChatGPT to give me more riddles, and I doubt it will run out of them.
I also learned how to code using Markdown.
Overall, I learned:

Pattern recognition: I practiced looking past the literal and finding answers that fit abstract clues.
Creative thinking: I considered multiple interpretations (like ‚Äúwindchime‚Äù vs.¬†‚Äúecho‚Äù) and stretched my imagination.
Confidence building: I solved the second riddle correctly ‚Äî showing that trusting my reasoning can pay off.
Playful problem-solving: I engaged with something fun that also sharpened my mind‚Äôs flexibility.

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: Artwork with ChatGPT
text:
Like many people, I have a professional headshot ‚Äî clean, simple, a little serious. But I wondered: what if I could see myself reimagined in totally different art styles?
So I tried it.

Studio Ghibli Me
I decided I want to turn my headshot into a Studio Ghibli version. For reference, these are the anime movies that Studio Ghibli makes. I uploaded this picture:

This was the command:
Can you turn my headshot into a Studio Ghibli version?
This was the picture I received:

Suddenly, I look like I belong in Spirited Away or Howl‚Äôs Moving Castle.


Bratz Me
Then, I got curious and inspired. What about other artstyles?
I entered this command:
What about in Bratz's style?
Bratz is an American fashion doll and media franchise that got popularized in the early 2000s.

I have the oversized eyes, glossy lips, and playful look straight out of a 2000s toy commercial.


More, More, More!
Once I started, it was hard to stop imagining possibilities:

Disney Princess style
Anime sh≈çnen hero
Barbie doll style
Picasso cubism portrait
Video game avatar

I especially wanted to try the last one.
Can you make me into a video game avatar?
This is what I got:

It‚Äôs so cute and definitely more realistic than the previous ones ChatGPT created! Maybe I‚Äôll upload this picture onto Instagram‚Ä¶
What other styles should I try next?
